instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00928: What is 820-00928? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.CD3215: What is CD3215? This is a USB-C muxing chip responsible for USB-C communication with devices such as the laptop charger. The most common issue this chip is involved in is when a Macbook wonâ€™t charge or the charger is stuck at 5v instead of going to 20v..
definitions.SMC_RESET_L: What is SMC_RESET_L? SMC_RESET_L puts the SMC into reset mode when it is low, _L means the signal is present when voltage is low. The SMC being in reset mode keeps it from running..
definitions.PP3V3_UPC_XB_LDO: What is PP3V3_UPC_XB_LDO? PP3V3_UPC_XB_LDO is an LDO coming out of the CD3215 USB-C muxing/charging chip. This can be shorted to ground by the capacitor on its line, and when this happens, the chip can stop functioning which causes the charger to not turn on..

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00928</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> stuck on 5V
threads.message: hello guys , have got <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00928</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> that's stuck on 5V. have got PP3V42 including <SIGNAL>PP3V3_UPC_XB_LDO</SIGNAL>, my <SIGNAL>SMC_RESET_L</SIGNAL> is high , all the i2c lines are high as well , I don't have a short to ground , the machine was not liquid damage . I have the <SIGNAL>PP1V8_UPC_XA_LDOD</SIGNAL> , I would like to know what else do I need for me to get 20V output or do I need to replace the whole <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP>? again at what point is it oaky to actually replace the <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP>, what must be present

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00928</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> stuck on 5V
threads.message:
First check <SIGNAL>BUF_SMC_RESET_L</SIGNAL>.
If OK, compare diode mode readings on power rails of all <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP> chips.

Any voltage at F7000?
Check diode mode there too...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00928</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> stuck on 5V
threads.message: <SIGNAL>BUF_SMC_RESET_L</SIGNAL> is present  at 3.3V , and  F7000 is about 0.02V am now checking on the diode measurements

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00928</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> stuck on 5V
threads.message: have got a quick question, is it possible to have a failure on a line that's already has it preset value ? for example , am comparing diode mode to ground on the power rails of the <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP> even though these where present , so does that mean their presence does not suggest the lines being okay ? please explain to me

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00928</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> stuck on 5V
threads.message:
Readings on similar rails of all <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP> chips must be almost equals.
Even if you get expected voltage, bad reading can be clue for internal problem.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00928</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> stuck on 5V
threads.message: thank you for the explanation.I compared the diode mode readings to a working board and they match,

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00928</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> stuck on 5V
threads.message:
Do you get similar values between all chips of non-working board?
Same I/V behaviour an all USB-C ports?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00928</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> stuck on 5V
threads.message: same in in all , compared to a working board

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00928</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> stuck on 5V
threads.message:
Could be <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP>, or even SMC issue.
Try replacing <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP> chips one by one; same code termination, of course.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00928</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> stuck on 5V
